text: my needle drops anthony fantano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new holograms
album forever
[Music]
holograms are a swedish post-punk outfit
who last year put out their full-length
debut on captured tracks records a nice
fast intense little self-titled album
and now about 14 months later here we
are with a new
full length it's another installment of
post punk revivalism and as you guys may
know i am not usually one to just praise
nostalgia for the sake of nostalgia but
i think there have been some inventive
and refreshing acts to sort of toy with
these darker sounds in post-punk music
as of late but when it comes to
holograms i do feel like they are
distinct the banned songs are pretty
steeped in these classic post-punk and
synth-punk influences however in my
opinion on their last full-length album
they made up for this issue easily with
just some raw energy and some really
catchy songwriting with singles like abc
city or deeper tracks on the record like
orpheo or memories of sweat the band's
performances just had this intense
energy the vocals while over the top and
maybe a little out of control were
really passionate and captivating while
stylistically holograms wasn't really
adventurous i do feel like they had this
art of post-punk songwriting down to a
hard science and i did like the fact
that the band's approach was kind of
poppy and just instantaneous
however i feel like on this new record
of theirs forever they're trying to
change their sound in their direction up
a little bit i really think the band is
trying to come off loftier a bit darker
on this thing with moodier guitars a bit
more reverb all over
everything and an increase in the use of
synthesizers and synthesizers of a
different tone too on the band's last
full-length lp whenever a synth would
hop into a track it was usually bright
loud and noisy whereas on this album the
synthesizers are much smoother much more
darker like they would slide really
nicely into a joy division single or
like a goth rock song and we do see
holograms on this record experimenting
with trying to write longer songs on the
whole of the album not really dropping
in for just a one minute and 40 second
bash fest while i do appreciate that the
band made an attempt to change and
believe me this is a change that they
needed to make but here i feel like
they're taking away some of that raw
energy and trying to build up their
songs without a solid foundation case in
point one of the things they string
these songs out with guitar solos guitar
solos that are not really that exciting
and just kind of feel like the band is
putting it there just to pad the song
out like on the song of sacred state the
opener to this album or the song at
stupa whose title is actually more edgy
than its guitar playing it's actually a
reference to this practice in nordic
society where elderly people or those
who are just no longer of use to the
town that they were living in would just
sort of hop off this cliff to their
death but let it be known that there are
some people that do not even believe
that this practice was common or even
existed still for a song title this
gloomy and for a band this ferocious on
a majority of its songs the guitar solo
here just kind of feels like a very tame
and limited rehash of the theme melody
of this song itself now occasionally i
do feel like holograms ambition pays off
like the rush of building drums and
rolling snares on the track rush with
these intense guitars just tightly
locking in with them i feel like
holograms have reached a new level of
tightness with this track especially
with the
incredibly climactic finish to this song
really loud really powerful and there is
the closing track on here to lay us down
which for me is the only honest-to-god
ballad on this album not a bad thing i
love that the band comes through with
some slightly more melodic vocals and
some really huge tubular bells what
sounds like tubular bells on the chorus
just building the track higher and
higher but for every triumphant moment
for me there is at least one kind of
underwhelming spot and even though
holograms last full-length record wasn't
really all that original i do feel like
that album did have some kind of element
of diversity to it you had these harder
faster more in your face tracks poppier
tracks slower more depressing songs that
are bleak as hell but on forever it
seems like holograms is trying to
deliver a series of variants on the same
synth-backed gothpunk song now there are
tracks on here that stick out like flesh
and bone or meditations songs that are a
testament to the fact that hologram
still has an immense talent for hook
writing which really makes refrains as
basic and as simple as i'm so tired
pretty freaking catchy and something
that most likely you will be singing
along with by the end of the song
especially since the vocals are so
passionate and the band repeats some of
these refrains a lot of times overall i
didn't really hear anything on this
album that i thought was awful and i
still enjoy the songs that dropped ahead
of the release of forever a lot i feel
like they stick out on their own but
when you bring them all together this
album becomes this homogenous piece of
post-punk revivalism i'm feeling a
strong six on this record
transition if you've given this
holograms album a listen
what did you think of it did you love it
hate it
why what do you think i should review
next and that's about it only the strong
subscribe all mistakes were intentional
this review is only my opinion also i
want to mention that i have a new music
video review video over at the maker
youtube channel go check that out via a
link down there or on my face and
that's it anthony fantano
holograms forever
forever
